wordpressPost.title: Employee Engagement News Roundup 10/02/2015
wordpressPost.content:
The WeSpire Employee Engagement Weekly News Roundup aggregates the top employee engagement articles from around the industry to keep you informed and inspire positive impact in your organization.

4 Essential Practices to Engage Employees

Gallup has found that only 13% of the workforce, across 142 countries, is engaged at work. Disengaged employees can be detrimental to a company: they are unproductive, monopolize their managers’ time, undermine their coworkers, and make more errors. Author Jeff Hollender’s experience shows that engaging employees through sustainability programs can drastically help to close the employee engagement gap. He provides insight into best practices and examples of existing platforms that will give your company the turn-around it needs.

Obama Uses Behavioral Science. Should You?

Governments and marketers have been using behavior science for years to try and effectively reach their audiences’and a lot of good has come from it. As one example from policy showed, simplifying the financial aid application process led to a large increase in college applications and attendance rates. Why? Because students were overwhelmed and confused with the previous process. Behavior science requires experimentation, trial and error’ research, and intense data analysis. So, how can organizations use it to lead to impactful positive outcomes for their business, stakeholders, and community?

How to Unlock the Power of Soft Skills

Corporate culture isn’t a new phenomena in the workplace; some companies design their own while others rely on their defaults. However, some of the most powerful company cultures out there got that way by design and the optimization of employee soft skills,’ such as teamwork, an eye for quality, and problem-solving. The most successful companies have figured out that using language and values that reflect both their internal and external efforts have been vital to their growth. Culture change, much like behavior change, doesn’t happen in a day. No matter where your company falls on the spectrum, the author offers advice on how to make small changes in order to support and motivate your organization towards success.

Coaching Makes All the Difference

According to Bersin by Deloitte, organizations that are effective at coaching saw a 33% increase in effectively engaging their employees, 42% higher productivity and 130% stronger business results. Knowing this’and as companies enter the fourth quarter of the year’the author urges businesses to embrace a culture of coaching. Doing so creates a sense of teamwork, instills trust in relationships, and demonstrates commitment to employee personal growth. Our favorite advice: You manage inventories. You coach people.

5 Ways to Help Your Employees Feel Empowered

Employees only act as empowered as their employers make them feel. So, when trying to lead employees to success or change employee behavior, having a clear vision and goal to work towards is the first step. Once that is in place, the author advises that managers should provide feedback, recognition, and support when necessary. Employees thrive when they know their efforts are seen, therefore actively empowering employees creates an environment and audience that welcomes continuous improvements.
